claim: If A is older than B, and A is older than C, then B is older than C

supporting.text: Age is a transitive relation; if A is older than B and A is older than C, it does not imply any direct relationship between B and C.

attacks.text: Age is a transitive relation; if A is older than B and A is older than C, it does not imply any direct relationship between B and C.
If A is older than B and A is older than C, and B and C share the same birthdate, then B and C are equally old, contradicting the claim that B is older than C.
In most real-world cases, birthdates are unique, so the scenario where B and C share the same birthdate is statistically rare.
If A is older than B and A is older than C, but B was born before C, then B is older than C, supporting the claim.
The claim is a general statement and does not account for specific cases where B might be older than C, making it an overgeneralization.

supporting.text: The given premises only establish that A is the oldest among A, B, and C, but do not provide information about the relative ages of B and C.
